item.title: Testing in a Monorepo
item.description: Testing Web Components While any test framework can work, it’s better to test web components in a browser environment because that’s where they’ll be used. Node-based frameworks would require too much shimming of DOM calls that’d make the tests unrepresentative. and are good options for browser-based testing. is powered by ES-build, and so is the client-side of the app; let’s go down this path and see where it leads.

item.title: Of Builds and Bundlers
item.description: Moving to TypeScript entails configuring how the JavaScript will be eventually consumed by both the server and the client. Separating the Client Bundle from the Server Bundle The server code runs in Node while the client code runs in the browser. advises separating the configurations for advantages like faster type-checking and compiling, lower memory usage when using an editor, and improved enforcement of the logical groupings of your program.
